title: Colchester United are backing Her Game Too campaign
body_text:
COLCHESTER United believe their new partnership with the Her Game Too campaign will be the perfect match.
The U's have linked up with the voluntary organisation, which campaigns for an inclusive and safe environment in football for female spectators and players.
The U’s are backing the campaign’s ethos of football being a game for all and ambition, to ensure stadiums are safe and welcoming places for women and girls to enjoy watching and playing football.
READ MORE: Danny Cowley's message amid Colchester's fine form
Her Game Too was formed by 12 female football fans in 2021 to help tackle sexism and misogyny in sport and has grown to incorporate more than 130 volunteers at football clubs across the country.
Colchester United joining the campaign means all 24 League Two clubs are now partnered with Her Game Too and 80 in total throughout the Premier League and English Football League, as well as hundreds of grassroots clubs and leagues and clubs in other sports including cricket, rugby and ice hockey.
U's fan Louise Harris will be spearheading the promotion of the campaign at the JobServe Community Stadium, as the club’s Her Game Too Ambassador.
Louise said: “I am really proud and excited to be Colchester United’s Her Game Too Ambassador.
“I’ve supported Colchester United for as long as I can remember and experienced the highs of Wembley twice - including nine minutes of magic when we were beating Chelsea and getting promoted to the Championship!
“I am really passionate about the club and want to make it as safe and comfortable for all female fans to attend games.
“We have such an amazing, loyal fanbase and a real family friendly feel at the club.
“The work done by the club, our Community Foundation and the BWA (Blue and White Army) to make match days special is something every fan should be proud of.
READ MORE: Braintree boost survival hopes with impressive away win
“I know a lot of our players, staff and fans have daughters and as a mum myself I’m sure we all feel it is really important to bring them up knowing everyone is welcome at our football games.
“I can’t wait to get started and plan our first Her Game Too and Colchester United dedicated fixture.”
Her Game Too operates a reporting line in partnership with Kick It Out, through which spectators can report incidents of sexism or misogyny at games or online.
It also promotes female inclusion within football through a range of events and projects such as the First Time Fans initiative, which introduces new female fans to football in a welcoming group environment.
The U’s Community Foundation’s values are ‘to inspire, enrich and unite our communities’, aligning perfectly with Her Game Too’s principles to help create amazing experiences in sport, no matter what your gender or ethnicity.
Colchester United’s Head of Media, David Gregory, said: “We are delighted to be working with Her Game Too, an organisation that has been doing a fantastic job in helping to create inclusive and supportive environments across football and sport.
“Colchester United as a club have always welcomed everyone to the JobServe Community Stadium, and the link up with Her Game Too will solidify that strongly-held belief that football is a sport for all.
“Having worked in football previously and now attending both the men’s and women’s games home and away with her daughter, we think that Louise Harris will be the perfect ambassador for us and Her Game Too.
“We look forward to a positive and productive future with Her Game Too and welcome them into the Colchester United family.”
To find out more about Her Game Too, visit www.hergametoo.co.uk
